content.description: This is a great route that probably has not seen more than a handful of ascents. As always I am in awe of Greg Lowe's ability- as this route was reportedly climbed without cams or sticky rubber-well before the free climbing revolution. When I did it I cleaned bushels of lichen and scale out of the crack. The rock at the start is pretty bad-both due to nesting birds showering the approach slab in debris in the area and simply being chossy granite in general. Once you get to the roof, the rock improves, the protection is great and the climbing is amazing. I think this route is the best hardish roof crack at the city of rocks- way better climbing than Skinners Roof!(for my big hands) With more ascents it will only get better.
content.protection: Cams from thin fingers to big hands. No bolts, no anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the west side of the building blocks formation. It is the left of the two obvious parallel roof cracks- it is approx 15 Ft long and 35-40 degrees overhanging. You can walk off (a slow round about path you pick down the south west side of the formation that ends with a squeeze chimney- and requires some 5.7ish down climbing) or perhaps it would be better to rap another route if you can.

content.description: Climb up crack until it ends at horizontal. Then shove out with some sequencing through the horizontal(same horizontal that eventually leads into Technocolor arete and Techno-Weenie). Then pull onto arete and finish on last half of Technocolor arete. A bit pumpy but short lived, with some airy movement traversing to the left through the horizontal. Entering the horizontal from the lower crack is a wee bit tricky, unless your tall.
content.protection:
gear for lower crack(finger sized) , small nuts, bolts,

anchors:bolts with chains
content.location: Located direct right of Technocolor arete and directly left of Scraps. Look for homemade hanger up by the horizontal crack.

content.description:
The second line from the right on the West face of Building Blocks.   Starts in a steep crack with good holds through a gear-protected boulder problem (easier for taller folk), then up easier terrain before a thrilling, well-protected roof.  I won't give up the beta but it's a blast!

Listed as "potentially loose" in the Bingham guide, most of the Building Blocks routes have cleaned up to make it a top-tier City crag.  The rock was generally excellent, with one obviously loose block in a crack but that was it.
content.protection:
Single set up to a 2 or 3 Camalot.  The cruxes are well protected and short, so get on it!

Anchors are right next to

Acid Rain's

, so it's easy to toprope too.

content.description: This is a high quality line just to the left of Lego.  Follow a blunt arete with bolts (1st crux) to hand crack and mini roof.  The second crux fires through the steep face above.  Once you find the sequence (it took me 4-5 tries), the moves are straight forward.  The upper plated face is protected with small to large nuts.  A great climb...
content.protection: 4-5 bolts, blue alien to #1 camalot, good selection of nuts...
content.location:
Scraps

is located on the west face just left of

Lego

.

content.description:
This is a pretty decent climb.  The difficulty overall and the crux are both determined by the precise path you take, but the way we did it felt to be in the lower 5.10 range.  The rock was pretty solid and good gear opportunity was plentiful enough to keep a a leader safe even if pushing their limits.  Though the book suggests a difficulty of "10/11" I failed to find a line any harder than 5.10-.  I thought it was fairly similar in grade to 'Acid Rain.'

Start off in the smaller cracks and some edges, about 5.9 (?) then continue up moderate climbing toward an inset with many crack options.  We took the most direct line and encountered a crux bulge about 1/2 way up the only felt 5.10-.  Belay up top, then rap down as for Lego.
content.protection: A standard rack from nuts to cams.  A double set of cams might be useful if you place a lot of gear.
content.location:
This climb ascends the center of the West Face via a trad line.  It is the obvious crack system to the left of the huge roofs of 'Vice Grips' and just right of the bolted line (and popular warm-up), 'Lego.'

Start on finger cracks and face holds and finish on jams and buckets.

content.description: Start on top of a large flake and follow three bolts to the base of the column. A long runner is helpful here at the 4th bolt. Follow well spaced bolts up crack and face climbing. This section is slightly overhanging and is the best part of the route. Wild moves and exposure leads to a chain anchor. You should consider rapping or bringing long runners for the anchors.
content.location: This route leads up the west face along the tallest column.

content.description:
Fun diversion with a bit of rope drag up nice features to the summit ridge, then over to the anchor on Lego.

Climb up thin cracks and face just left of the imposing roof area of Vicegrips.  Traverse out the diving board feature atop that roofy area.  Climb up steep face on good features to a nice finish hand crack at the top.
content.protection:
Gear from .5" to 4".  No fixed gear and no anchor directy on top of route.

Long slings nice for any gear placed near the traverse up the slanting diving board feature.  Rope drag can be an issue on this route!

Traverse to anchor on Lego for a rappel to the ground.
content.location:
Located to the right of the 5.10/5.11 "Trad Line" area mentioned in the DB guide.  Just left of the "Vice Grips" area.

Rappel Lego.

content.description:
Locate the route at the far climbers right of the west face.  Start left and climb up and right along a wide crack and series of huecos.  Place gear, 0.5 or 0.4 cam, or continue to solo to the first bolt.  Move up to a ledge, another opportunity for gear, #1 camalot or if you are tall, clip the 2nd bolt. Climb up and left along the ramp to gain the summit.

This is an hidden classic! The first bolt is 30ft off the deck, but you can fiddle a medium hex at 20ft. Follow fun patina plate climbing to a crux roof. You get cool exposure as you climb patina edges along a leaning arete.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchors, optional medium hex
content.location: The right most bolted line on the west face
